page.title: 03HOLYWELL-LOURDES OF WALES
page.content: The'healing waters'of the'holy well'of {St.Winefride}have been a{place of {pilgrimage}for centuries.Legend tells how St.Winefride spurned the advances of Prince Caradoc,who in his rage,cut off her head.Where her head touched the soil,a clear fountain of water sprang forth.In the 12th century some Cistertian Monks began a thriving farming community at{Basingwerk Abbey and by 1797 the torrent from the Well had been harnessed to power corn and cotton mills,copper and brass works. The 1.5miles of valley which links the Well and Basingwerk saw the dawning of the{Industrial Revolution in N.Wales and Holywell prospered to become a leading world centre for lead mining during this period.Pantasaph's found- ation stone was laid in 1858. By 1875 the Capuchin Friars had constructed their 14 Stations of the Cross.
